You can get an overview of the functionality at this wiki page:

https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Precedence+Feature+Notes

For more detail and custom policies, you'll need to dig into the source 
code for the related classes (as listed on that wiki page), and possibly 
implement your own subclasses.

Some thoughts about using these functions:

� some related benefits can also be addressed with the 'budgeting' 
(CostAssignmentPolicy) features � essentially nudging the crawler to 
spend proportionately more time on some queues than others

� the queue and URI precedences were designed with the idea that there 
would be a handful (or maybe dozens) of tiers, not hundreds or thousands 
� so I wouldn't rely on this (especially the URI precedence) for very 
fine-grained control. (In particular, many URI priorities means many 
different insertion points for varied URIs in a single queue, which 
means more disk seeks/less cache efficiency on the queue structures.)

� URIs only get their precedence when initially enqueued; they can't be 
reprioritized within their queue later. (Queues can have their 
precedence changed as their size/contents/other-heuristics change.)

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA


On 4/15/11 1:50 AM, tashev85 wrote:
>
>
> Hello Gordon,
>
> I am working on a customization of Heritrix and I need exactly those two features. However, I could not find any information on how to use them. Could you please explain in more detail (or point me to the documentation) how to assign priorities to different queues while running a job and how to assign priorities to URIs when they are inserted into the queues.
>
> Thanks in advance.
>
>
>> If you want your prioritization to also take effect within the standard
>> Heritrix frontier queues, there's a (seldom-used) pair of features,
>> queue and URI 'precedence' values, which affect (1) how inactive queues
>> are sorted while waiting for their chance to be active; (2) where URIs
>> are inserted into individual queues (if all the other factors which
>> affect whether they are pushed-near-the-top or queued-to-the-back are
>> equal).
>>
>
>
>
